title: 105_hr3307
content: The "Education for Life Act of 1998" may be cited as the short title. Modifications to Education Individual Retirement Accounts are included in the Act. The "Education for Life Act of 1998" includes amendments to Section 530(b)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, defining qualified education expenses for elementary and secondary education, higher education, and job training expenses. The Education for Life Act of 1998 includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code, defining qualified education expenses for elementary and secondary education, higher education, and job training expenses. This includes tuition, fees, tutoring, special needs services, books, and supplies. The Education for Life Act of 1998 defines qualified education expenses for elementary and secondary education, including tutoring, special needs services, books, supplies, computer equipment, transportation, and other necessary expenses for enrollment at a school. This also covers expenses for homeschooling if state or local laws are met, with "school" defined as any institution providing education up to grade 12. Qualified job training expenses include tuition, fees, books, supplies, equipment, and allowances for meals and lodging for workers in an applicable training program. Increase in maximum contributions to education individual retirement accounts under the Code, with amendments to age limits and conforming adjustments. The retirement account contribution limits are increased from $500 to $2,500. Additionally, a new section is added for deductions for contributions to education individual retirement accounts. The contribution limits for education individual retirement accounts are increased to $2,500. The deduction allowed for education individual retirement accounts is limited to $2,500 per individual under age 55. No deduction is allowed for rollover contributions or payments made by employers. Employer payments to education individual retirement plans are treated as compensation to the employee, regardless of deduction eligibility. A deduction for contributions to education individual retirement accounts is allowed under section 222 of the Code. The table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by adding new items. Sec. 222 and Sec. 223 discuss contributions to education individual retirement accounts. Subparagraph (B) of section 530(d)(4) of the Code is amended to remove penalties for distributions not used for education expenses after the beneficiary turns 59 1/2. Additionally, age limitations are waived for children with special needs in section 530(b) of the Code. The age limitations in section 530(b) of the Code do not apply to designated beneficiaries with special needs. Corporations are allowed to contribute to accounts, with maximum amounts specified for individual contributors. These amendments will be effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1998.
